title: Ticket #1184: fstat() fails in procapi for large inodes in /proc
description:
We noticed 32-bit condor on 64-bit systems sometimes producing errors messages such as the following: 

ProcAPI: fstat failed in /proc! (errno=75)

I tracked this down to entries in /proc with inode values too big to represent in the 32-bit stat structure. Example: 

$ stat /proc/249577/stat
  File: `/proc/249577/stat'
  Size: 0         	Blocks: 0          IO Block: 4096   regular empty file
Device: 3h/3d	Inode: 18446744072885960717  Links: 1
Access: (0444/-r--r--r--)  Uid: (    0/    root)   Gid: (    0/    root)
Access: 2010-02-04 12:22:36.023594484 -0600
Modify: 2010-02-04 12:22:36.023594484 -0600
Change: 2010-02-04 12:22:36.023594484 -0600

The solution is to use the LFS call fstat64() when available.

The consequence of this problem would be a wrong uid associated with a tracked process (it assumes the process belongs to root). This could lead to leaked processes when using a dedicated execution account to do process tracking.
remarks:
2010-Feb-04 16:52:08 by matt:
It almost seems like Condor should require fstat64's presence. Otherwise someone could compile, only get fstat and run into this bewildering problem, which would appear to be fixed.
